-1295221725 12 11----Verdict----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	interior:1 last:1 gener:1 exterior:1 overal:1 suitabl:1 substanti:1 enough:1 heat:1 center:2 avoid:1 seat:2 button:1 combin:1 varieti:1 chunki:1 luxuri:1 right:2 cool:1 control:2 get:1 form:1 intuit:1 scroll:1 provid:1 bit:1 marvel:1 outgo:1 materi:2 attent:1 suffici:1 panel:1 model:1 put:1 can:1 wheel:2 redund:1 quick:1 click:1 heavili:1 evolut:1 fit:1 share:1 easi:1 best:1 read:1 sometim:1 displai:1 want:1 beneath:1 asid:1 pad:1 acronym:1 task:1 physic:1 come:1 hint:1 receiv:1 overload:1 instrument:1 technolog:2 school:1 dash:1 mount:1 bolster:1 comfort:1 steer:1 lie:1 step:1	||	Putting the acronyms aside and getting comfortable in the driver's seat, you can see why the exterior is just an evolution of the outgoing model. The interior received the lion's share of the attention. The seats are heavily padded and provide suitable bolstering; they're also heated and cooled, and come in a variety of materials. The dash is easy to read and the steering wheel is sufficiently chunky with just enough redundant controls to avoid technological overload. The center instrument panel is fitted with all the right buttons for all the right tasks. If you don't see it in physical form, a few quick clicks of the center-mounted scroll wheel that controls the display will get you what you want, sometimes in a less-than-intuitive way. Overall, the materials are a substantial step up from the last generation, and do their best to combine a bit of old-school luxury with a hint at the technological marvels that lie beneath.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: acronyms; driver; seat; exterior; evolution; model; lion; share; attention; seats; variety; materials; dash; wheel; controls; overload; center instrument panel; buttons; tasks; form; clicks; scroll wheel; display; way; materials; step; generation; bit; luxury; hint; marvels; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
-1295221725 12 12----DriveRide----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	equip:1 vehicl:2 fx:1 highwai:1 torqu:1 expect:1 band:1 given:1 aluminum:1 buyer:1 rpm:1 power:2 mileag:1 option:1 mute:1 certainli:1 provid:1 pedal:1 size:1 content:1 outgo:1 strong:1 better:2 citi:1 util:1 spec:1 attempt:1 ride:1 call:1 weight:2 set:1 engin:1 road:1 hand:1 damper:1 affair:1 versu:1 ampl:1 fuel:1 feel:1 stamp:1 penalti:1 linear:1 previous:1 endur:1 sport:3 come:2 punish:1 produc:1 ut:1 kidnei:1 seem:1 point:1 steer:1 suit:1 emphas:1 engag:1 plenti:1 burbl:1 motiv:1	||	On the road, both the V8-powered FX50 and V6-equipped FX35 feel like a handful of other 'utes that are attempting to emphasize the "Sport" in Sport Utility Vehicle. The ride is certainly better than the outgoing FX and even with the dampers set to Sport it's not the kidney-punishing affair we previously endured. The steering isn't what we'd call engaging, but it's what we've come to expect from vehicles of this size and weight. Power from the V6 is ample, with a linear torque band that seems to come into its own above 2,500 rpm, while the V8 produces a muted burble out back and provides plenty of motivation when you stamp down on the aluminum long pedal. Both engines have their strong points, but given the weight penalty of the V8 and the better fuel mileage of the V6 (16/21 city/highway for the V6 versus 14/20 for the V8), most buyers would be content with an FX35 optioned up to suit their own specs.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: FX; 	NOUN: road; FX50; FX35; handful; utes; Sport; Sport Utility Vehicle; ride; FX; dampers; Sport; affair; steering; vehicles; size; weight; Power; V6; torque band; rpm; V8; burble; plenty; motivation; aluminum; pedal; engines; points; weight penalty; V8; fuel mileage; V6; city\/highway; V6; V8; buyers; FX35; specs; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
-1295221725 12 13----DriveRide----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	last:1 foot:1 infin:1 fx:2 impal:1 half:1 nice:1 beyond:1 center:1 help:1 time:1 pole:1 tree:2 page:1 seat:2 wildfir:1 mile:1 year:1 along:1 dirt:1 place:1 curv:1 prove:1 victim:1 bag:2 california:1 flat:1 behind:1 prevent:1 involv:1 opportun:1 start:1 impress:1 nurseri:1 got:1 util:1 poorli:1 stop:1 topsoil:1 give:1 set:2 next:1 coupl:1 babi:1 road:1 push:1 southern:1 oak:1 suv:1 best:1 gestur:1 playboi:1 undul:1 twenti:1 back:1 capabl:1 hint:1 front:1 us:2 hour:1 fold:1 fire:1 rout:1 wast:1 point:1 larg:2 understat:1 steer:1 occup:1 engag:1 laid:1 part:1 destin:1 recoveri:1	||	About twenty miles from our starting point, we stopped into a nursery so Infiniti could prove that the FX is both an engaging steer and an SUV with Utility. With the seats folded flat, two five-foot baby oak trees were placed in the back, along with two bags of dirt, all of which was destined for a fire recovery center set up to help victims of the wildfires that laid to waste a large part of Southern California last year. It was a nice gesture, but couldn't have been more poorly timed. The route they'd set us on involved more curves and undulations than on the pages of Playboy, and with two trees and a couple bags of topsoil behind our backs, we did our best over the next two-and-a-half hours to prevent one of the large poles from impaling the front seat occupants. To say that we never got the opportunity to push the FX beyond 5/10ths would be an understatement, but it did give us a hint of the FX's capabilities on the back roads. We were less than impressed.	##false@@false$$		||	LOCATION: FX; Southern California; 	NOUN: miles; point; nursery; Infiniti; FX; SUV; Utility; seats; baby oak trees; bags; dirt; fire recovery center; victims; wildfires; part; Southern California; year; gesture; route; curves; undulations; pages; Playboy; trees; couple bags; topsoil; backs; hours; poles; seat occupants; opportunity; FX; 5\/10ths; understatement; hint; FX; capabilities; roads; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Steering inputs are masked with a thin layer of Novocain; shifts are somewhat sluggish and the paddle shifters aren't nearly as immediate as they need to be. It can be outfitted with most of the techno toys from its larger, V-8 powered stablemate. With 303 horses (up from 275 in the previous FX35), performance is hardly shabby, with the 0-to-60 blast taking just 6.1 seconds. On the road, the Compass felt seriously underpowered, its engine wheezing and whining as the vehicle lethargically made its way up hills. At highway speeds, mashing the accelerator or slapping the Autostick shifter caused the continuously variable transmission (CVT) to select a lower virtual gear and make considerably more mechanical noise, but actual acceleration was all but absent.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Compass; engine; horsepower; pound-feet; torque; engines; road; Compass; engine; vehicle; way; hills; highway speeds; accelerator; slapping; Autostick shifter; transmission; CVT; gear; noise; acceleration; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

It's a solid, sophisticated, 16-valve engine. It features electronic variable valve timing that continually changes the torque curve, bringing more versatility to the 165 peak pound-feet of torque, and more capability to the 172 peak horsepower. Emphasis during development of this engine was on fuel mileage; even carrying 3326 pounds, the Compass 4WD with a five-speed manual transmission delivers EPA fuel economy estimates of 22/27 mpg City/Highway.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Chrysler; Mitsubishi; Hyundai; EPA; 	NOUN: Jeep Compass; Chrysler; World Engine; century efficiency; Mitsubishi; Hyundai; engine; valve timing; torque curve; versatility; peak pound-feet; torque; capability; peak horsepower; Emphasis; development; engine; fuel mileage; pounds; Compass 4WD; manual transmission; EPA fuel economy estimates; mpg City\/Highway; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1642963153 5 15----Exterior----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	car:1 liberti:1 wheel:1 truck:1 line:2 door:1 angular:1 compass:2 smaller:1 version:1 patriot:3 introduc:1 hand:1 compact:1 sent:1 jeep:1 side:1 suv:2 command:1 especi:1 throwback:1 similar:1 look:3 direct:1 cheroke:1 vertic:1 charact:1 smoothli:1 preserv:1 rear:1 crossov:1 sculpt:1 masculin:1 handl:1 upright:2 mount:1 base:2 brand:1 laid:1 pillar:1 flare:1	||	Jeep sent its brand in a new direction in 2007, introducing two car-based SUVs, the Compass and Patriot. Of the two, the Compass has more of a crossover look, especially from the sculpted side, with smoothly angular flares over the wheels and more laid back lines. The rear door handles are vertical, mounted on the C-pillars to preserve the character line. (The Patriot, on the other hand, is more upright, looking like a smaller version of the Commander and a throwback to the old Cherokee. Jeep's other compact SUV is the truck-based Liberty. It looks similar to the Patriot, but is even more upright and masculine.)	##false@@false$$		||	DATE: 2007; 	NOUN: Jeep; brand; direction; SUVs; Compass; Patriot; Compass; crossover look; side; flares; wheels; lines; door; C-pillars; character line; Patriot; hand; version; Commander; throwback; Cherokee; Jeep; SUV; Liberty; Patriot; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1642963153 5 22----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	rectangular:1 ralli:1 plastic:2 last:1 singl:1 ergonom:1 intellig:1 nice:1 round:1 gaug:1 race:1 spoke:1 heat:1 disc:1 center:2 fm:1 forward:1 button:1 seat:1 year:1 pleasant:1 lever:1 black:3 knob:1 option:1 ring:1 control:1 white:1 avail:1 wide:1 solid:1 system:1 honda:1 stereo:1 sprout:1 match:1 cheap:1 stack:2 posit:1 tan:1 nicer:1 cd:1 car:1 realli:1 wheel:1 trade:1 chrome:2 symmetr:1 grip:1 add:1 navig:1 automat:1 introduc:1 clean:1 layout:1 practic:1 trim:2 hard:1 grai:1 top:1 look:1 includ:1 matter:1 silver:1 vent:1 origin:1 variou:1 climat:1 manual:1 dash:2 steer:1 grain:1 instead:1 actual:1 shift:1 design:1	||	The dash is now black instead of tan or gray. It's also more rounded and has nicer graining than last year, but it's still made of hard plastic. The center stack trades a cheap-looking silver plastic for matching black and adds some nice chrome trim. The center stack is wide and intelligently designed: rectangular vents on top, a single-disc AM/FM/CD stereo or the navigation system below it, and below that are three climate control knobs and various buttons for options (including the available heated seats). The gauges are clean and pleasant, white on black with a symmetrical layout and chrome trim rings. The four-spoke steering wheel is solid to grip. The shift lever, manual or automatic, sprouts from the dash. This practical high forward position was introduced by Honda, but actually originated in rally racing cars, where ergonomics really matter.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Honda; 	NOUN: dash; tan; graining; year; plastic; center; silver plastic; center; vents; top; AM\/FM\/CD stereo; navigation system; climate control knobs; buttons; options; seats; layout; chrome; rings; steering wheel; grip; shift lever; manual; sprouts; dash; position; Honda; rally racing cars; ergonomics; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

It's relatively smooth and quiet for a four-cylinder in a vehicle with these prices. This is Chrysler's World Engine and it uses the latest technology, including an aluminum block and cylinder heads, and electronically controlled variable valve timing that helps optimize torque. It makes a reasonable 172 horsepower and 165 pound-feet of torque at 4400 rpm, and delivers an estimated 22/27 City/Highway miles per gallon with AWD and the five-speed manual gearbox, or 21/24 mpg with AWD and the CVT automatic.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Chrysler; CVT; 	NOUN: engine; Jeep Compass; vehicle; prices; Chrysler; World Engine; technology; aluminum block; cylinder heads; valve timing; torque; horsepower; pound-feet; torque; rpm; City\/Highway miles; gallon; AWD; manual gearbox; mpg; AWD; CVT; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

It just takes some forethought and bit of patience to get it to do what you might demand. Jeep hasn't quoted 0-60 mph times, but a manual transmission model with the 2.4-liter engine is probably in the mid-to-low nine-second range. We'd expect the automatic to be about a half second slower and 2.0-liter models to be one to two seconds slower. Those estimates are adequate, but not near the best in the class. The Compass can also tow up to 2000 pounds, enough for personal watercraft, a snowmobile, a motorcycle or a small boat.	##false@@false$$		||	DATE: 2000; 	NOUN: Sport; pounds; acceleration; Compass; dog; forethought; bit; patience; Jeep; mph times; transmission model; engine; range; half; models; seconds; estimates; class; Compass; pounds; watercraft; snowmobile; motorcycle; boat; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1642963153 5 32----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	kick:1 variabl:1 bend:1 natur:1 possibl:1 wait:1 harsh:1 transaxl:1 nois:1 cylind:1 knock:1 jeep:1 alwai:1 mile:1 year:1 work:1 avail:1 continu:1 upshift:1 impress:1 auto:3 make:1 stick:2 smooth:1 quick:1 compass:1 transmiss:1 automat:1 six:1 lane:1 easili:1 immedi:1 brake:1 sharp:1 speed:1 crisp:1 us:2 hour:1 past:1 accuraci:1 pass:1 manual:2 felt:1 per:1 downshift:3 featur:1 instead:2 improv:1 chang:1 competitor:1 shift:2	||	We like the Auto Stick's manual shift feature. Jeep has made changes to improve noise and harshness each of the past two years, but no four-cylinder is as smooth as the V6s available in some competitors. We were impressed by the crisp and immediate upshifts and downshifts using the six-speed Auto Stick. The nature of the continuously variable transaxle makes such quick shifts possible. The Auto Stick in the Compass is as sharp as any manual automatic we've felt. With such accuracy, it always works: easily downshifting to knock off a few miles per hour for bends, instead of using the brakes; or downshifting to pass on a two-lane, instead of waiting for the transmission to kick down on its own.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Auto Stick; shift feature; Jeep; changes; noise; harshness; years; V6s; competitors; upshifts; downshifts; Auto Stick; nature; transaxle; shifts; Auto Stick; Compass; accuracy; miles; hour; bends; brakes; two-lane; transmission; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1642963153 5 33----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	wander:1 oregon:1 reveal:1 wood:1 jounc:1 sealant:1 good:1 feedback:1 hit:1 jeep:1 jar:1 none:1 along:1 head:1 liber:1 work:1 wind:1 turn:1 portland:1 wallow:1 steadi:1 aim:1 materi:1 sound:1 toss:2 silent:1 cabin:1 wheel:2 adhes:1 structur:1 pothol:1 ocean:1 road:1 bump:1 compass:1 hand:1 thank:1 side:2 deaden:1 isol:1 transmit:1 corner:1 trace:1 us:1 suspens:1 secur:1 rippl:1 steer:1 plai:1 pacif:1	||	Along the winding wooded roads between Portland, Oregon, and the Pacific Ocean, the Compass revealed itself to be steady and silent thanks to liberal use of sound deadening material, sealants and structural adhesives. The suspension does all the work as it should, isolating the cabin from the bumps and tosses. We aimed for potholes and weren't jarred when we hit them. There was none of the old Jeep head-toss, or side-to-side jouncing, and there was no trace of wallow over ripples. Only the good feedback was transmitted through the steering wheel to our hands. The turn-in for corners was secure, with no play in the wheel or wandering.	##false@@false$$		||	LOCATION: Portland; Oregon; Pacific Ocean; 	NOUN: roads; Portland; Oregon; Pacific Ocean; Compass; thanks; use; material; sealants; adhesives; suspension; work; cabin; bumps; tosses; potholes; none; Jeep head-toss; jouncing; trace; wallow; ripples; feedback; wheel; hands; turn-in; corners; play; wheel; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1642963153 5 34----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	virtual:1 need:1 markedli:1 call:1 percent:1 freedom:1 wheel:3 can:1 coupl:1 road:1 compass:1 stage:1 elsewher:1 center:1 jeep:2 drive:2 electron:1 clutch:1 rather:1 power:1 effici:1 control:1 dry:1 flat:1 lock:1 traction:1 rear:1 front:1 much:1 viscou:1 system:3 magnet:1 design:1 shift:1 differenti:1	||	Jeep has designed a new all-wheel-drive system for the Compass, which it calls Freedom Drive I. On a dry, flat road, virtually all of the power goes to the front wheels, but as traction is needed elsewhere, as much as 60 percent can shift to the rear wheels. The coupling is through a two-stage clutch system that's magnetic and electronically controlled, rather than viscous, and Jeep says this is markedly more efficient. The system also has a locking center differential.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Jeep; system; Compass; Freedom Drive I.; road; power; wheels; traction; percent; wheels; coupling; clutch system; Jeep; system; center; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

We slammed on the brakes at about 40 mph, and the ABS with rough-road detection worked hard but successfully.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Compass; ESP; ABS; 	NOUN: Compass; miles; gravel roads; direction; limits; Compass; round stones; tires; ESP; couple; times; ditches; brakes; mph; ABS; detection; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1642963153 5 36----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	vehicl:1 dune:1 beach:1 infinit:1 toward:1 gear:1 jeep:1 oper:1 rang:1 wrangler:1 power:1 effici:1 deep:1 option:1 limit:1 except:1 told:1 avail:1 number:1 amazingli:1 provid:1 tire:1 peopl:1 floor:1 ratio:1 belt:1 climb:2 allow:1 goodyear:1 engin:2 compass:2 pullei:1 reach:1 mean:1 cvt:2 top:1 terrain:1 transmit:1 sand:2 steep:1 ideal:1 sport:1 us:1 atv:1 steel:1 nearest:1 point:1 stai:1 mechan:1 summit:1	||	When we reached the beach, we climbed into a Compass Sport with the CVT and optional Goodyear Wrangler all-terrain tires that aren't available with the Limited. The Jeep people pointed toward the top of the nearest steep sand dune and told us to floor it. Amazingly, the Compass climbed to the summit, where there were no other vehicles except ATVs. The CVT is the ideal mechanical means for transmitting engine power in deep sand, because its pulleys and steel belt provide an infinite number of gear ratios, allowing the engine to stay in its most efficient operating range.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: CVT; Goodyear; CVT; 	NOUN: beach; Compass Sport; CVT; Goodyear Wrangler; tires; Limited; Jeep people; top; sand dune; floor; Compass; summit; vehicles; ATVs; CVT; means; engine power; sand; pulleys; steel belt; number; gear ratios; engine; operating range; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1642963153 5 37----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	vehicl:1 wheel:2 can:1 goodyear:1 distribut:1 possibl:1 road:1 compass:1 difficult:1 torqu:2 mud:1 lightn:1 electron:1 snow:1 mile:1 spin:1 best:1 evenli:1 stuck:1 modul:1 brake:2 individu:1 turn:1 control:2 transfer:1 dab:1 get:1 speed:2 imagin:1 calcul:1 slip:1 lock:2 traction:2 sport:1 hour:1 offer:1 tire:1 begin:1 point:1 radiu:1 per:1 stand:1 start:1 base:1 keep:2 differenti:2	||	It's difficult to imagine getting stuck in snow or mud in the Compass Sport with the Goodyear on/off-road tires. The locking differential can offer the best possible traction from a standing start, and the Brake Traction Control dabs the brakes (at lightning speed) at individual wheels to keep them from spinning. The locked differential keeps the torque evenly distributed at 50/50, up to 10 miles per hour, at which point the torque begins transferring again, as calculated by the electronic control module based on vehicle speed, turning radius and wheel slip.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Goodyear; Brake Traction Control; 	NOUN: snow; mud; Compass Sport; Goodyear; tires; differential; traction; standing start; Brake Traction Control; brakes; lightning speed; wheels; torque; miles; hour; torque; control module; vehicle speed; radius; wheel; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1642963153 0 10----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	mph:1 mpg:4 drone:1 second:1 wheel:2 test:1 variabl:1 engin:2 horribl:1 highwai:1 compass:2 zero:1 automat:1 torqu:1 transmiss:2 went:1 cylind:1 drive:2 combin:1 fuel:1 horsepow:1 cvt:2 option:1 liter:1 racket:1 standard:2 speed:1 feet:1 come:1 number:1 front:1 capabl:1 continu:1 manual:2 economi:1 improv:1 glacial:1 citi:1 pound:1	||	Every Compass comes standard with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine capable of 172 horsepower and 165 pound-feet of torque. Fuel economy with the automatic and 4WD is 21 mpg city/24 mpg highway and 22 mpg combined. Although the ride is fairly comfortable over smooth blacktop, the cabin is not well isolated from wind and road noise (although more sound deadening for 2009 should help this somewhat). Around town, the Compass is a bit more enjoyable, as its large wheels and tires, direct steering and compact dimensions make it quite maneuverable. 1642963153 7 1----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	vehicl:1 pun:1 seriou:1 road:1 compass:2 contrast:1 level:1 jeep:3 wrangler:1 year:1 direct:1 ye:1 groaner:1 vener:1 entri:1 irresist:1 true:1 meant:1 us:1 crossov:1 point:1 differ:1 debut:1 ago:1 world:1	||	The Compass pointed to a new direction for Jeep when it debuted two years ago. And yes, the pun is an irresistible groaner, but it's also true. The Compass was and is the first Jeep crossover, and the first Jeep not to be meant for serious off-road use. 1642963153 7 2----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	prowess:1 anywher:1 vehicl:1 segment:1 door:1 kei:1 amount:1 compact:1 alwai:1 wrangler:3 demand:1 turn:1 dream:1 remov:1 enter:1 avail:1 suggest:1 continu:1 solid:1 bodi:1 frame:1 market:1 sacrific:2 nich:1 definit:1 popular:1 make:1 car:1 wheel:1 axl:1 road:3 compass:1 fit:1 readili:1 map:1 current:1 mean:1 best:1 driver:1 built:1 ancestor:1 windshield:1 us:1 crossov:1 fold:1 vagu:1 urban:1 orient:1 comfort:1 manner:1 construct:1 certain:1 daili:1	||	A Luddite's dream, the Wrangler continues to be built in the manner of its ancestors, with body-on-frame construction, solid axles, removable doors, and a fold-down windshield. It's still the best new turn-key four-wheeled off-road vehicle readily available. Which means that it makes sacrifices for its off-road prowess. Using a Wrangler as a daily driver anywhere where "road" is more than a vague suggestion on a map demands a certain amount of sacrifice of comfort. There will always be a niche for the Wrangler, but it definitely doesn't fit into what is one of the most popular current car market segments, urban-oriented compact crossover. For that, enter the Compass.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Luddite; dream; Wrangler; manner; ancestors; construction; axles; doors; windshield; vehicle; sacrifices; prowess; Wrangler; driver; road; suggestion; map; amount; sacrifice; comfort; niche; Wrangler; car market segments; crossover; Compass; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

It shares chassis and drivetrain with the Dodge Caliber, which means unibody construction, fully-independent suspension, front- or single-range active four-wheel drive. Unlike most 4WD crossovers, the Compass's "Freedom Drive I"(tm) system has a lockable center coupling, which allows it to better handle low-traction situations such as deep snow, sand, or mud.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Dodge Caliber; 	NOUN: Crossover; car comfort; SUV styling; Compass; chassis; drivetrain; Dodge Caliber; construction; suspension; front; drive; crossovers; Compass; Freedom Drive; tm; system; center coupling; situations; snow; sand; mud; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

As is the Jeep convention, "Limited" denotes top-of-the-line specification, although various option packages enable a Sport to nearly meet a Limited there, or for the Limited to be even fancier. Power is from parent Chrysler's 172-horsepower 2.4-liter "World Engine", matched to either a five-speed manual or continuously-variable (CVT) transmission, although the front-drive Sport may be had with a smaller, 2.0-liter, 158-hp version of the World Engine, matched to the CVT for improved fuel economy. With the signature seven-vertical-slot grille, round (ok, oval) headlights, and trapezoidal wheel arches in athletic but not muscle-bound flared fenders, it could only be a Jeep, and bears a more-than-passing resemblance to the first-generation Liberty. It does -- appropriately -- have a more car-like, or crossover-like, look, with a sloping, curved windshield (flat, fold-down not spoken here...) arched roofline (with built-in luggage rack, of course), triangular D-pillars, and decidedly un-boxy proportions and profile. The unibody structure features a central safety cage and front and rear crumple zones for further protection in case of an accident. Antilock brakes with Brake Assist, traction control, and the Electronic Stability Program with the Electronic Roll Mitigation extension are also standard safety equipment in all Compasses. 1642963153 7 9----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	unlimit:1 need:2 via:1 vehicl:1 backwood:1 rock:1 good:1 macpherson:1 camp:1 independ:1 mud:1 damp:1 seat:1 jeep:2 slope:1 snow:1 wrangler:2 pave:1 deep:1 ski:1 flat:1 job:1 multilink:1 sleep:1 tune:1 tire:1 ramp:1 clearanc:1 lot:1 citi:1 small:2 littl:1 ride:1 climb:2 stream:1 wheel:1 roughneck:1 ingenu:1 ground:1 road:1 compass:3 summertim:1 puddl:1 fit:1 strut:1 trip:1 ford:2 fine:1 park:1 inch:1 depend:1 come:1 fulli:1 pretens:1 fold:1 handl:1 slick:1 suspens:1 drivewai:1 comfort:2 suit:1 insid:1 local:1 slicker:1 mall:1	||	RIDE AND HANDLING:	##true@@false$$	The Compass is a city slicker with no pretension to being a backwoods roughneck. Need a small Jeep to ford streams, climb rocks, and get through deep mud or snow? Get a Wrangler or Wrangler Unlimited. Need a small Jeep to ford the puddle in your driveway, climb the ramp to the mall parking lot, or get to the local ski slopes via paved, if slick, roads? Those are jobs for which the Compass is suited. Its fully-independent MacPherson strut/multilink suspension is tuned for comfort but has good damping. With 8.1 to 8.4 inches of ground clearance depending on the wheels and tires fitted, a Compass should be a fine vehicle for camping trips come summertime, and with a little ingenuity and all those fold-flat seats you could even sleep inside in comfort.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: MacPherson; 	NOUN: Compass; city slicker; pretension; roughneck; Jeep; streams; climb rocks; mud; snow; Wrangler; Wrangler Unlimited; Jeep; puddle; driveway; ramp; mall parking lot; ski slopes; slick; roads; jobs; Compass; MacPherson; suspension; comfort; inches; ground clearance; wheels; tires; Compass; vehicle; camping trips; summertime; ingenuity; seats; comfort; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1642963153 7 10----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	need:1 concert:1 tm:1 freedom:1 singl:1 variabl:1 possibl:1 good:1 perform:1 torqu:4 necessari:1 esp:1 sensor:1 cylind:1 stroke:1 although:1 time:1 band:1 oper:1 jeep:1 drive:3 rang:2 rpm:2 dubiou:1 ft:1 effici:1 twincam:1 option:1 work:1 control:1 transfer:1 liter:1 job:1 alloi:1 system:2 surfac:1 winter:1 acceler:1 simul:1 ratio:1 lb:1 low:1 displac:1 can:1 wheel:3 engin:1 convert:1 coupl:1 automat:1 mode:1 six:1 transpar:1 territori:1 electron:2 horsepow:1 cvt:1 valv:1 condit:1 softwar:1 travers:1 regular:1 camshaft:1 lock:1 rear:1 us:1 manual:1 autostick:1 widen:1 larg:1 suit:1 ab:1 rel:1 mid:1 shift:1	||	PERFORMANCE:	##true@@false$$	With 172 horsepower (at 6000 rpm) and 165 lb-ft of torque (at 4400 rpm), the Compass's 2.4-liter twincam alloy four-cylinder engine is well-suited for its job. Its long stroke, relatively large displacement, and variable valve timing on both camshafts widen the torque band, for good low- and mid-range acceleration. The optional CVT is more efficient than a regular torque-converter automatic, and "AutoStick"(tm) manual shifting (by software simulation of six ratios) is possible but necessary only for traversing dubious surfaces - Jeep territory. The "Freedom Drive I" single-range four-wheel drive system uses electronic sensors and an electronically-controlled coupling to transfer torque to the rear wheels as needed, and works in concert with the ABS and ESP systems. It is transparent in operation, although it can be locked in four-wheel drive mode for winter conditions.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: CVT; ABS; 	LOCATION: ESP; 	NOUN: PERFORMANCE; horsepower; rpm; lb-ft; torque; rpm; Compass; twincam alloy; engine; job; stroke; displacement; valve timing; camshafts; torque band; acceleration; CVT; AutoStick; tm; software simulation; ratios; surfaces; Jeep territory; Freedom Drive; drive system; sensors; coupling; torque; wheels; concert; ABS; ESP systems; operation; drive mode; winter conditions; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1642963153 8 21----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	model:1 stream:1 send:1 wheel:2 rock:1 slipperi:1 compass:1 situat:1 mode:1 time:1 level:1 jeep:1 drive:1 electron:1 power:1 ford:1 brake:1 major:1 control:2 awd:1 standard:1 sibl:1 speed:1 lock:1 rear:1 traction:1 crawl:1 front:1 avail:1 us:1 stabil:1 system:3 divert:1 base:1 method:1 ab:1 enhanc:1 competitor:1 thing:1	||	While this Jeep won't crawl over rocks and ford streams like its siblings, it is available with an all-wheel-drive system that sends power to the front wheels the majority of the time but diverts some to the rear when things get slippery - the method used by most competitors. 1457348628 4 5----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	drone:1 compound:1 perform:1 powerpl:1 cylind:1 expect:2 hesit:1 brisk:1 drive:2 power:1 lineup:1 work:1 coars:1 liter:3 unfortun:1 teen:1 charact:1 provid:1 present:1 loud:1 acceler:1 better:1 economi:2 citi:1 compar:1 decent:1 otherwis:1 might:2 unrefin:1 engin:1 automat:1 vastli:1 fuel:2 especi:1 note:1 speed:1 forgiven:1 choic:1 refin:1 problem:1 aveng:2 offer:4 around:1 differ:1 lose:1 dodg:2 downshift:1 term:1 experi:1 base:1 exhaust:1 mid:1 rel:1 passabl:1	||	As you might expect, the three engine choices on the 2009 Dodge Avenger lineup offer vastly different driving experiences. The 2.4-liter four-cylinder is especially unrefined, with its loud and coarse exhaust note and ever-present drone, which might be forgiven if only it offered decent power. Unfortunately, it doesn't, and the problems are only compounded by the four-speed automatic, which hesitates for downshifts but is otherwise passable. The 2.7-liter V-6 offers better all-around performance but loses out in terms of fuel economy when compared to the base offering. The R/T's 3.5-liter powerplant works well in the Dodge Avenger, providing brisk acceleration and a relatively refined character; expect fuel economy in the mid teens in city driving.	##false@@false$$		||	DATE: 2009; 	NOUN: engine choices; Dodge Avenger lineup offer; experiences; exhaust note; drone; power; problems; downshifts; V-6; performance; terms; fuel economy; base offering; R\/T; powerplant; Dodge Avenger; acceleration; character; fuel economy; teens; city driving; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The expensive Dodge Avenger R/T offers some unique trim pieces, but overall the intimation of budget materials remains. For a mid-size sedan, however, the 2009 Dodge Avenger impresses in terms of interior space; the 2009 Dodge Avenger can easily hit its capacity claim of five adults, thanks to the generous headroom and legroom measurements, and the trunk is sized well. Anti-lock brakes come standard on the Dodge Avenger SXT and R/T models, but unfortunately are not available on the SE. Electronic stability control, an invaluable feature that has saved many lives, is only offered as an option on the R/T. In government safety tests, the 2009 Dodge Avenger earns a five-star rating in frontal crash tests and a similar five stars in the side impact test for front occupants, though rear occupants only receive four-star protection. However, the agency says that the door became unlatched in the side test, increasing the likelihood of ejection. In the insurance industry's IIHS tests, the Avenger scores "good" ratings for front and side protection.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Dodge Avengers; IIHS; 	DATE: 2009; 2009; 	NOUN: Dodge Avengers; array; safety features; side; airbags; omissions; brakes; Dodge Avenger SXT; R\/T models; SE; stability control; feature; lives; option; R\/T; government safety tests; Dodge Avenger; rating; crash tests; stars; side impact test; occupants; occupants; protection; agency; door; side test; likelihood; ejection; insurance industry; IIHS tests; Avenger scores; ratings; front; side protection; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Both engines can come with either a four- or six-speed automatic transmission. Reviewers think the base engine is sufficient, but some note that it has trouble getting the sedan up to speed. They prefer the V6 engine for its strong power delivery and good fuel economy. Fuel economy from the base engine is among the worst in the class, at 21/29 mpg city/highway. The Avenger s handling falls on the sporty side of the spectrum, and test drivers appreciate its lively demeanor, limited body roll and comfortable ride. They agree that it is one of the more engaging midsize cars to drive. The front-drive Avenger chassis shared with the Sebring was designed from the beginning for a convertible as well as a sedan, and that means that it is extraordinarily stiff and strong. It's also designed to meet all of the crash regulations aimed at pedestrian safety and get multiple five-start crash ratings, too.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Dodge Avenger; Chrysler Sebring; 	NOUN: Dodge Avenger shares; systems; components; Chrysler Sebring; means; clone; Avenger chassis; Sebring; beginning; sedan; crash regulations; safety; crash ratings; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1457348628 9 2----Price----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	consol:1 interior:2 singl:1 segment:1 entertain:1 same:1 heat:1 center:1 cooler:1 cylind:1 although:1 seat:1 drive:1 drink:1 buyer:1 combin:1 option:3 custom:1 cool:1 sibl:1 cubic:1 minivan:1 tradit:1 largest:1 huge:1 sebr:1 bodi:1 system:2 market:2 price:1 sedan:1 start:1 lot:2 dashboard:1 car:1 wheel:1 engin:1 rounder:1 space:2 navig:1 someth:1 reach:1 passeng:1 style:1 suv:1 look:1 includ:1 entri:1 rear:1 feet:1 front:1 offer:2 aveng:2 beverag:1 storag:1 satellit:1 around:1 chrysler:1 differ:2 dodg:1 featur:2 radio:1 part:1 competitor:1 design:1 found:1	||	The sibling entry, the Chrysler Sebring, although it starts at about the same price, is a rounder, more traditional design for a different customer. The Dodge Avenger will reach out to those buyers looking for something different in a huge part of the market that offers a lot of sameness: front-wheel drive, four-cylinder or V6 engines, around 100 cubic feet of interior space, navigation, satellite radio and lots of interior storage spaces. This is the largest single passenger-car market segment, and very few of the competitors have the combination of style, features and options that the Avenger offers. Those features include a drink cooler in the dashboard, an optional beverage cooling/heating system in the center console, and an optional rear-seat entertainment system in a sedan body (most are found in minivans and SUVs).	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Chrysler; Dodge Avenger; 	NOUN: sibling entry; Chrysler Sebring; price; rounder; design; customer; Dodge Avenger; buyers; something; part; market; lot; sameness; front-wheel drive; V6 engines; feet; space; navigation; satellite radio; lots; storage spaces; passenger-car market segment; competitors; combination; style; features; options; Avenger offers; features; drink cooler; dashboard; beverage; system; center console; rear-seat entertainment system; sedan body; minivans; SUVs; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The SE comes standard with 16-inch steel wheels, a tilt-and-telescoping steering wheel, full power accessories, air-conditioning, cruise control, a cooled front storage compartment and a four-speaker audio system with a single-CD player, satellite radio and an auxiliary audio jack. The Avenger SXT bumps the standard wheel size to 17 inches and adds a rear spoiler, foglights, steering-wheel-mounted audio controls, stain-resistant cloth upholstery, an eight-way power driver seat, a fold-flat passenger seat and two more speakers and a six-CD changer for the audio system. 1457348628 0 20----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	equip:1 lower:1 good:1 perform:1 highwai:1 disc:1 cylind:1 although:1 level:1 option:1 sxt:1 stronger:1 hold:1 class:1 sluggish:1 acceler:1 better:1 distanc:1 economi:1 low:1 ride:1 stop:1 model:1 unrefin:1 line:1 grip:1 full:1 setup:1 fuel:1 drum:1 trim:1 heavi:1 brake:2 feel:2 fade:1 corner:1 unimpress:1 rear:1 come:1 averag:1 us:1 aveng:3 offer:1 quickli:1 gearchang:1 remain:1 dodg:1 comfort:1 expens:1 rel:1	||	The four-cylinder Avenger offers good fuel economy, but it comes at the expense of performance. On models with rear drums, the brakes fade quickly with heavy use, and although the full-disc setup on V6-equipped Avengers holds up better, stopping distances remain long for this class. 1457348628 7 11----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	phone:1 sporti:1 ts:1 segment:1 midsiz:1 entertain:1 occupi:1 heat:1 gigabyt:1 spot:1 cylind:1 antiskid:1 basic:1 file:1 drive:4 malibu:1 fusion:1 leather:1 option:3 cool:1 control:1 except:1 sxt:3 liter:4 awd:2 compani:1 hold:1 cell:1 parent:1 mark:1 avail:2 se:3 curtain:1 size:1 digit:1 sebr:1 pictur:1 system:2 upholsteri:1 honda:1 start:1 sedan:1 chevrolet:1 remot:1 got:1 antilock:1 otherwis:1 car:1 model:4 hp:1 connect:1 wheel:1 link:1 camri:1 engin:3 navig:1 transmiss:1 automat:2 toyota:1 six:1 airbag:2 wireless:1 share:1 side:2 horsepow:2 stratu:1 ford:1 hard:1 brake:1 similar:1 music:1 safeti:1 taller:1 includ:3 assum:1 audio:1 standard:1 inch:1 speed:2 dvd:1 traction:1 return:1 sport:1 us:1 front:3 aveng:4 accord:1 came:1 cuphold:1 suspens:1 chrysler:1 featur:1 competitor:1 design:1	||	New for 2008, the Avenger marked Dodge's return to the midsize-sedan segment. Assuming the spot once occupied by the Stratus, Avenger was about 4 inches taller than that car, but otherwise similar in size. Avenger shared its basic design with the Sebring from Dodge's parent company, Chrysler. Competitors included the Chevrolet Malibu, Ford Fusion, Honda Accord, and Toyota Camry. SE, SXT, and sporty R/T and R/T AWD models were available. SE and SXT came with a 173-horsepower 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine. A 189-hp 2.7-liter V6 was optional for SXT, while R/T models got a 235-horsepower 3.5-liter V6. The R/T AWD models had all-wheel drive, but all other Avengers were front-drive. The 2.4- and 2.7-liter engines used a four-speed automatic transmission; the 3.5, a six-speed automatic. Front-drive R/Ts had a sport suspension. Standard safety features included antilock brakes (except SE models), curtain side airbags, and front side airbags. Traction control and an antiskid system were available. Optional was a navigation system with digital-audio connectivity, wireless cell-phone link, and a 20 gigabyte hard drive that could hold music or picture files. Other options included a heated and cooled cupholder, remote engine start, leather upholstery, and DVD entertainment.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Dodge; Stratus; Dodge; Chrysler; Chevrolet Malibu; Ford Fusion; Honda; SXT; 	PERSON: Avenger; 	DATE: 2008; 	NOUN: New; Avenger; Dodge; return; segment; spot; Stratus; Avenger; inches; car; size; Avenger; design; Sebring; Dodge; parent company; Chrysler; Competitors; Chevrolet Malibu; Ford Fusion; Honda Accord; Toyota Camry; SE; SXT; R\/T; R\/T AWD models; SE; SXT; engine; 2.7-liter V6; SXT; R\/T models; 3.5-liter V6; R\/T AWD models; drive; Avengers; engines; transmission; R\/Ts; sport suspension; Standard safety features; brakes; SE models; side airbags; side airbags; Traction control; system; navigation system; connectivity; cell-phone link; gigabyte; drive; music; picture files; options; cupholder; engine start; leather upholstery; DVD entertainment; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1457348628 7 35----Reliability----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	increas:1 result:1 vehicl:1 decreas:1 incorrectli:1 abil:1 impact:1 dealer:1 pivot:2 mai:2 free:1 requir:1 frontal:3 event:1 repair:1 built:1 crash:2 condit:1 presenc:1 safeti:1 support:1 align:1 instal:1 injuri:1 aveng:1 potenti:1 system:1 effect:1 charg:1 compromis:1 steer:3 column:3 occup:1 load:1 rivet:2 inspect:1 miss:1	||	2011 Avenger:	##false@@false$$	Vehicles may have been built with a missing or incorrectly installed steering column pivot rivet. As a result, the condition may increase the potential for injury in a frontal crash. Dealers will inspect for rivet presence and alignment and repair the steering column pivot as required, free of charge.	##false@@false$$		||	DATE: 2011; 	NOUN: Avenger; Vehicles; column; rivet; ability; column; occupant loads; event; crash; effectiveness; impact safety system; result; condition; potential; injury; crash; Dealers; rivet presence; alignment; column; charge; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

-295017622 1 2----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	model:1 lower:1 mpg:2 don:1 wheel:3 test:1 outfit:1 engin:2 good:1 epa:1 highwai:2 though:1 priorit:1 estim:1 although:1 rate:3 drive:4 suv:2 buyer:1 power:1 fuel:1 driver:1 especi:1 fine:1 dynam:1 safeti:1 get:1 receiv:1 borrego:4 avail:1 handl:1 bodi:1 frame:1 reliabl:1 better:1 base:2 economi:1 competitor:1 citi:2	||	The base Borrego gets better fuel economy than most other body-on-frame SUVs, although those estimates are lowered when the Borrego is outfitted with four-wheel drive and a V8 engine. -295017622 1 3----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	car:1 truck:1 overal:1 midsiz:1 kia:2 good:1 sai:1 introduc:1 center:2 mai:1 time:1 gripe:1 transport:1 automak:1 shopper:1 suv:3 rather:1 focus:1 develop:1 option:1 find:1 complaint:1 look:1 famili:1 lifestyl:1 choic:1 borrego:2 crossov:2 tradit:2 main:1 seven:1 better:1 comfort:1 base:2 suit:1 didn:1 maneuver:1 review:1	||	Most reviewer complaints about the 2009 Borrego didn t center on the SUV itself. Rather, their main gripe was about Kia s timing, saying that Kia introduced a traditional truck-based SUV when most other automakers were focused on developing car-based crossovers. Overall, if a traditional SUV suits your lifestyle, the Borrego is a good choice. But shoppers looking for comfortable, maneuverable, family-centered transportation for seven may find that a midsize crossover is a better option.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Kia; Kia; 	PERSON: Borrego; Borrego; 	DATE: 2009; 	NOUN: reviewer complaints; Borrego didn t center; SUV; gripe; Kia; timing; Kia; SUV; automakers; crossovers; SUV suits; lifestyle; Borrego; choice; shoppers; transportation; crossover; option; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

During the 1990s and into the new millennium, even companies that historically stuck to cars jumped on the SUV bandwagon, developing their own versions of utility vehicles to satisfy consumers' ravenous appetites for road-going monstrosities. But oh, how times have changed. As fuel prices continue to rise, more consumers are turning back toward smaller, fuel-efficient vehicles, and some automakers have even responded by cutting back production of their larger vehicles to focus on the small car market. But not Kia. The Korean company is betting there's still some life in the midsize SUV segment -- and the stakes are in the form of the new 2009 Kia Borrego.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Kia; 	DATE: 2009; 	LOCATION: Kia Borrego; 	NOUN: time; automakers; SUVs; millennium; companies; cars; SUV bandwagon; versions; utility vehicles; consumers; appetites; road-going monstrosities; times; fuel prices; consumers; vehicles; automakers; production; vehicles; car market; Kia; company; life; SUV segment; stakes; form; Kia Borrego; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Unlike crossovers, traditional body-on-frame SUVs are generally able to handle rougher terrain and boast higher towing capacities. Available with either a V6 or a V8 engine, the Borrego comes standard with features such as downhill brake control and hill assist control, and ground clearance is on par for the segment. Four-wheel-drive models also come with the expected two-speed transfer case. Notably, the Borrego can also tow up to a class-leading 7,500 pounds. On the downside, the Borrego seems to miss the mark when it comes to some aspects of performance and handling, and its lack of a power liftgate makes one wonder how a brand touting its advanced features could have overlooked something so relatively common.	##false@@false$$		||	PERSON: Borrego; Borrego; Borrego; Borrego; 	DATE: 2009; 	NOUN: Borrego; appearances; gizmos; chops; vehicle; crossovers; SUVs; terrain; boast; capacities; V6; V8 engine; Borrego; standard; features; brake control; hill; control; ground clearance; par; segment; models; transfer case; Borrego; pounds; downside; Borrego; mark; aspects; performance; handling; lack; power liftgate; wonder; brand; features; something; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The understated cabin is simple and refined, while a logical dash layout keeps the various controls relatively easy to use. The third-row seats are relatively easy to stow and put back into place, although cargo capacity with all seats up is a paltry 12.4 cubic feet. We assume two factors are to blame here. The rubber mounts between the body and frame, while they help absorb some shock and keep the vehicle quiet, contribute to a somewhat sloppy feel when going over bumps and potholes. Secondly, the suspension calibrations obviously have an even greater effect on ride quality. -295017622 8 11----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	vehicl:1 gmc:1 door:1 kia:1 uplevel:1 seat:3 rang:1 drive:3 option:1 limit:4 avail:2 third:1 pedal:1 tradit:1 row:2 curtain:1 system:3 upholsteri:1 start:1 low:1 wheel:4 durango:1 pair:1 truck:1 engin:2 line:1 usb:1 road:1 transmiss:1 six:1 lx:2 keyless:1 side:2 adjust:1 ford:1 ex:2 rearview:1 tilt:1 us:1 front:2 access:1 satellit:1 envoi:1 base:1 brand:1 radio:1 mid:1 construct:1 capac:1 competitor:1 mate:1 telescop:1 midsiz:1 type:1 heat:2 antiskid:1 level:2 gear:1 power:3 leather:1 control:1 liter:2 flat:1 mark:1 util:1 antilock:1 pound:2 model:1 hp:1 explor:1 navig:1 automat:2 airbag:2 passeng:1 automak:1 tow:1 suv:1 horsepow:1 exclus:1 trim:1 brake:1 top:1 safeti:1 includ:3 standard:3 audio:1 speed:2 camera:1 rear:2 traction:1 sport:1 borrego:3 capabl:1 offer:2 came:2 fold:1 korean:1 seven:1 dodg:1 steer:1 featur:3	||	Brand-new for 2009, the Kia Borrego was a midsize sport-utility vehicle from the Korean automaker. The Borrego marked Kia's first offering that was available with a V8 engine. This seven-passenger four-door SUV used traditional truck-type construction and came in three trim levels: base LX, mid-level EX, and top-of-the-line Limited. Power came from a 276-horsepower 3.8-liter V6 paired to a five-speed automatic transmission or a 337-hp 4.6-liter V8 that mated with a six-speed automatic. Both rear-wheel drive and four-wheel drive were offered. The 4WD models had low-range gearing for off-roading. LX V8s were 4WD-only. Limiteds were V8-only with rear- or four-wheel drive. Standard safety features included antilock brakes, traction control, an antiskid system, front side airbags, and curtain side airbags. Available features included an uplevel audio system, fold-flat second- and third-row seats, a navigation system, satellite radio, MP3 and USB capability, and a rearview camera. A power tilt/telescopic steering wheel, leather upholstery, and heated front seats were standard in the Limited and optional for the EX. Heated second-row seats, power-adjustable pedals, and keyless access and engine start were Limited-exclusive standard features. Towing capacity was 5000 pounds with the V6 and 7500 pounds with the V8. Borrego competitors included the Dodge Durango, Ford Explorer, and GMC Envoy.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Kia Borrego; Kia; EX; Dodge Durango; Ford Explorer; 	PERSON: Borrego; Borrego; 	DATE: 2009; 	LOCATION: Korean; 	NOUN: Kia Borrego; vehicle; automaker; Borrego; Kia; offering; V8 engine; SUV; construction; levels; base LX; EX; Power; 3.8-liter V6; transmission; 4.6-liter V8; rear-wheel drive; drive; 4WD models; off-roading; LX V8s; Limiteds; drive; Standard safety features; brakes; traction control; system; side airbags; curtain side airbags; features; uplevel audio system; seats; navigation system; satellite radio; MP3; capability; rearview camera; power; wheel; leather upholstery; seats; EX; second-row seats; pedals; access; engine start; features; Towing capacity; pounds; V6; pounds; V8; Borrego competitors; Dodge Durango; Ford Explorer; GMC Envoy; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1347394025 1 9----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	hp:1 model:2 mpg:4 can:1 edg:1 wheel:6 flow:1 highwai:1 epa:1 transmiss:1 automat:1 torqu:1 primarili:1 version:1 six:1 estim:1 level:1 slippag:1 drive:3 combin:1 fuel:1 power:3 redirect:1 trim:1 liter:1 awd:1 standard:1 speed:1 rear:1 feet:1 choic:1 front:3 offer:1 either:1 nearli:1 economi:1 case:1 citi:1 make:1 occur:1 pound:1	||	Powering the Edge is a 3.5-liter V6 that makes 265 hp and 250 pound-feet of torque. A six-speed automatic transmission is standard. All trim levels offer a choice of either front-wheel or all-wheel drive. On AWD models, power flows primarily to the front wheels until wheel slippage occurs, in which case nearly all the power can be redirected to the rear. EPA fuel economy estimates for front-wheel-drive versions are 17 mpg city/24 mpg highway and 19 mpg combined. Four-wheel-drive models get 15/22/18 mpg.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: EPA; 	NOUN: Edge; V6; hp; pound-feet; torque; transmission; levels; choice; front-wheel; drive; AWD models; power; wheels; wheel slippage; case; power; rear; EPA fuel economy; versions; mpg city\/24 mpg highway; mpg; models; mpg; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1347394025 1 12----Safety----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	govern:1 edg:2 test:5 highest:1 score:2 possibl:1 good:1 highwai:1 impact:3 disc:1 spot:1 airbag:2 mirror:1 passeng:2 avoid:1 rate:1 insur:1 frontal:2 full:1 side:4 seat:1 length:1 driver:1 offset:1 perfect:1 ford:1 institut:1 brake:1 crash:2 control:1 safeti:1 standard:1 rear:1 star:3 front:2 stabil:1 sweep:1 logic:1 curtain:1 rollov:1 nearli:1 earn:1 blind:1 antilock:1	||	Antilock disc brakes, stability control (with rollover avoidance logic), front-seat side airbags, full-length side curtain airbags and blind spot mirrors are all standard. In government crash tests, the 2009 Ford Edge nearly had a perfect sweep. It scored five stars (out of five) for the driver and four stars for the passenger in frontal impact tests, while it earned five stars in side impact testing for both front and rear passengers. In Insurance Institute for Highway Safety crash tests, the Edge scored the highest possible rating of "Good" in both frontal offset and side impact testing.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Insurance Institute for Highway Safety; 	DATE: 2009; 	NOUN: Antilock disc brakes; stability control; rollover avoidance logic; front-seat side airbags; side curtain airbags; spot; standard; government crash tests; Ford Edge; sweep; stars; driver; stars; passenger; impact tests; stars; impact testing; passengers; Insurance Institute; Highway Safety crash tests; Edge; rating; impact testing; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The layout is attractive and simple, though the materials and surfaces are a half step in look and feel behind the best rivals. Seating is a high point all around; front seats are ample and supportive, and in back the second row can recline to different degrees and is split 60/40 for flexible combinations of cargo and passengers. With the front passenger seat folded down, items measuring up to eight feet in length can be transported within the Edge. But the cargo area at the back is restricted a bit by the sloping rear window. It's not altogether sporty, though; there's some body lean if you go into a corner too quickly, but the Edge maintains its composure. While pedal feel is reasonably good, there's surprisingly little return without a firmer-than-normal braking foot. Peering through the spokes of those big wheels just adds aesthetic disappointment to the performance shortcoming. With Conestoga-sized wheels, the standard rotors and calipers appear puny. More rotor diameter would not only add visual horsepower, but might actually result in more responsive brakes to boot. At the very least, a color on the calipers would have been a nice touch, though perhaps it's better to avoid drawing any attention to the otherwise stock hardware.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Edge Sport; 	NOUN: Edge Sport; prowess; bit; letdown; rest; harmony; pedal feel; return; foot; spokes; wheels; disappointment; performance shortcoming; wheels; rotors; calipers; rotor diameter; horsepower; brakes; boot; color; calipers; touch; attention; stock hardware; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Gear changes do not slam harshly or snap heads, even at wide open throttle, and the optional all-wheel drive system flattens any torque steer that may try to rear its head. The front-drive Edge Sport would save you some bucks and a little weight, and AWD doesn't figure to be as helpful in foul weather thanks to those those big wheels and steamroller rubber. If you live where it snows, a winter wheel/tire package for this vehicle would be money well spent.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford; 	NOUN: Ford; 6F transmission; butter; age; self-shifters; Gear changes; heads; throttle; drive system; torque; head; Edge Sport; bucks; weight; AWD; weather thanks; wheels; steamroller rubber; winter wheel\/tire package; vehicle; money; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1347394025 5 11----Exterior----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	lower:1 vehicl:1 reason:1 cours:1 good:1 tip:1 venza:1 uniqu:1 rocker:1 tweez:1 million:1 extra:1 bargain:1 murki:1 bodi:2 chromei:1 titan:1 make:1 entir:1 upon:1 panel:1 might:1 edg:3 wheel:2 set:1 compel:1 someth:1 toyota:1 buck:1 ford:2 trim:1 exist:1 want:1 look:1 feel:1 perhap:1 larger:1 lock:1 rear:1 sport:3 front:1 tuck:1 thousand:1 fascia:1 either:1 color:1 take:1 gaze:1 actual:1 exhaust:1 alreadi:1 enhanc:1	||	At least the body enhancements look like a million bucks, making the extra thousands feel like a bargain when you set your gaze upon the Edge Sport. The unique lower fascias front and rear and rocker panels are body color, exhaust tips are larger on the Sports, and of course there are those chromey wheels, either as 20s or 22s. With the Edge Sport, Ford takes an already good vehicle and trims, tucks and tweezes it into something entirely more compelling. The actual reasons for the Edge Sport's existence might be murky perhaps Ford didn't want Toyota to have a lock on titanic wheels with its Venza.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford; Ford; Toyota; 	PERSON: Venza; 	NOUN: body enhancements; bucks; thousands; bargain; Edge Sport; fascias front; rear; rocker panels; body color; exhaust tips; Sports; course; wheels; Edge Sport; Ford; vehicle; trims; tucks; tweezes; something; reasons; Edge Sport; existence; Ford; Toyota; lock; wheels; Venza; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1347394025 5 12----Price----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	belong:1 wise:1 collar:1 perform:1 though:1 distinct:1 badg:1 uniqu:1 flirt:1 enjoi:1 among:1 buyer:1 focus:1 elit:1 place:1 gill:1 crash:1 live:1 behind:1 competit:1 cliqu:1 much:1 bit:1 price:2 attitud:1 touch:1 disciplin:1 lot:2 pleasur:1 tweak:1 prefer:1 big:1 wallop:1 parti:1 car:1 wheel:1 edg:4 drove:1 crush:1 pain:1 admittedli:1 add:1 someth:1 reach:1 mai:2 mildli:1 style:1 bone:1 horsepow:1 direct:1 look:1 exactli:1 sport:5 capabl:1 offer:3 wrought:1 differ:1 great:1 blue:1 comfort:1 instead:1 prestig:1 deliv:1 brand:1 insid:1 chang:1 stuf:1 competitor:1 detroit:1 yet:1	||	The Edge Sport delivers a lot to like. It's very comfortable, performs well and looks great. Price-wise, it's mildly painful and flirts with competition that, while admittedly focused on a different buyer, offers much more prestige for about the same price. There's a lot of pleasure to be had behind the wheel, though. We drove the Edge Sport all over the place while enjoying the change in attitude these tweaks have wrought. It may not be a sports car or stuffed to the gills with bone-crushing horsepower, but the Edge Sport does live up to its badging with a touch more capability and discipline, and it adds a big wallop of style inside and out that's unique among blue-collar Detroit offerings. That distinction may be exactly where the Edge Sport belongs, as it offers something that's a bit of a reach for the brand, yet has no direct competitors, preferring instead to crash the party of a more elite clique.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Edge Sport; Edge Sport; 	LOCATION: Detroit; 	NOUN: Edge Sport; lot; competition; buyer; prestige; price; lot; pleasure; wheel; Edge Sport; place; change; attitude; tweaks; sports car; gills; horsepower; Edge Sport; touch; capability; discipline; wallop; style; Detroit offerings; distinction; Edge Sport; something; bit; reach; brand; competitors; party; clique; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

It's 500 pounds lighter than an Explorer, enjoys an edge of two to three miles per gallon in fuel economy and offers similar advantages over other traditional SUVs. Benefiting from all-wheel drive and a fully independent suspension, the Edge is easier to control than a truck-based SUV in the snow or on wet, slippery roads. Getting in and out of it is easier, too. Yet it gives up nothing in passenger and cargo space. In fact, the back seats in the Edge are roomier than those in the Explorer, a benefit of its design.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: Edge; SUVs; cargo space; pounds; Explorer; edge; miles; gallon; fuel economy; advantages; SUVs; drive; suspension; Edge; SUV; snow; roads; nothing; passenger; cargo space; fact; seats; Edge; Explorer; benefit; design; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

1347394025 5 32----Exterior----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	proportion:1 wheel:2 edg:4 give:1 reason:1 bigger:1 overal:2 explor:2 road:1 closer:1 push:1 eight:1 short:1 length:2 relat:1 longer:1 mean:1 left:1 ford:2 right:1 look:1 outward:1 corner:1 inch:4 width:2 rear:1 track:3 speak:1 front:1 wide:1 photo:1 tire:1 wider:3 farther:1 stanc:1 overhang:1 distanc:2 wheelbas:3 shorter:2 yet:1	||	The Ford Edge is bigger than it looks in photos. The reason is that it has a wide track and a long wheelbase with short overhangs. The Edge is eight inches shorter in overall length than the Ford Explorer yet its wheelbase is just two inches shorter. Also, the track on the Edge is four inches wider while the overall width is just one inch wider. This means that, in relation to the Explorer and speaking proportionately, the Edge has it tires pushed farther outward, closer to the corners, both in length and width, which gives it a wider and longer stance on the road. (The track is the distance between the left and right wheels. Wheelbase is the distance between the front and rear wheels.)	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford Edge; 	NOUN: Ford Edge; photos; reason; track; wheelbase; overhangs; Edge; inches; length; Ford Explorer; wheelbase; inches; track; Edge; inches; width; inch; relation; Explorer; Edge; corners; length; width; stance; road; track; distance; wheels; Wheelbase; distance; front; wheels; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The long wheelbase and wide track are not just about looks; they make for a more stable vehicle because the majority of the mass is inside the wheels. Visually, this aggressive stance makes the Edge stand apart from the relatively tippy look of traditional SUVs.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: track; wheelbase; body; Edge look; wheels; corner; road; wheelbase; track; looks; vehicle; majority; mass; wheels; stance; Edge; look; SUVs; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Having its wheels out near the corners aids stability and handling. To bolster its chance for success, Ford set its suspension tuners upon the big CUV. The result is increased damping rates all around, stiffer rear springs and an additional millimeter of diameter for the front anti-roll bar, now 34mm.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford; 	NOUN: tires; street car; mass; hunks; metal; corner; vibes; wheel; chance; success; Ford; suspension tuners; CUV; result; rates; springs; millimeter; diameter; bar; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The Edge's normal poise is there, with noticeably tight rebounding that keeps ride motions on the well-disciplined side of firm. 1347394025 7 4----Verdict----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	edg:1 terribl:1 pull:1 brethren:1 snap:1 promis:1 engin:2 perform:1 admittedli:1 north:1 transmiss:1 automat:1 torqu:1 six:1 oper:1 horsepow:1 swing:1 plu:1 muster:1 liter:1 bai:1 gigundo:1 speed:1 sport:1 feet:1 hoop:1 needl:1 around:1 slick:1 differ:1 anyon:1 mechan:1 satisfi:1 deliv:1 ecoboost:1 pound:2 tachomet:1	||	Mechanically, the Edge Sport isn't terribly different from its other brethren. The same 3.5-liter V6 and slick-operating six-speed automatic transmission are here. The 265 horsepower and 250 pound-feet of torque that this engine delivers will pull the 4,000-plus pounds around with satisfying snap when the tachometer needle swings north. Admittedly, however, those gigundo hoops promise performance that the engine bay can't muster. EcoBoost anyone?	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Edge Sport; 	NOUN: Edge Sport; brethren; 3.5-liter V6; six-speed; transmission; horsepower; pound-feet; torque; engine; pounds; snap; tachometer needle swings; hoops; performance; engine bay; EcoBoost anyone; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1347394025 7 5----DriveRide----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	rotor:2 prowess:1 appear:1 foot:1 reason:1 calip:2 normal:1 nice:1 good:1 perform:1 spoke:1 though:1 draw:1 avoid:1 stock:1 conestoga:1 letdown:1 respons:1 aesthet:1 without:1 pedal:1 size:1 bit:1 visual:1 touch:1 harmoni:1 better:1 attent:1 rest:1 big:1 otherwis:1 littl:1 might:1 result:1 wheel:2 edg:1 add:2 puni:1 firmer:1 horsepow:1 diamet:1 brake:3 peer:1 surprisingli:1 feel:1 boot:1 disappoint:1 standard:1 perhap:1 return:1 color:1 mechan:1 actual:1 hardwar:1 shortcom:1	||	The Edge Sport's braking prowess is a bit of a letdown from the rest of the mechanical harmony. While pedal feel is reasonably good, there's surprisingly little return without a firmer-than-normal braking foot. Peering through the spokes of those big wheels just adds aesthetic disappointment to the performance shortcoming. With Conestoga-sized wheels, the standard rotors and calipers appear puny. More rotor diameter would not only add visual horsepower, but might actually result in more responsive brakes to boot. At the very least, a color on the calipers would have been a nice touch, though perhaps it's better to avoid drawing any attention to the otherwise stock hardware.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Edge Sport; 	NOUN: Edge Sport; prowess; bit; letdown; rest; harmony; pedal feel; return; foot; spokes; wheels; disappointment; performance shortcoming; wheels; rotors; calipers; rotor diameter; horsepower; brakes; boot; color; calipers; touch; attention; stock hardware; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
1347394025 7 6----Verdict----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	save:1 vehicl:1 snap:1 torqu:1 open:1 help:1 gear:1 drive:2 snow:1 weather:1 head:2 option:1 live:1 rubber:1 awd:1 respons:1 wide:1 figur:1 tire:1 monei:1 system:1 winter:1 throttl:1 packag:1 butter:1 big:1 try:1 littl:1 smooth:1 weight:1 steamrol:1 wheel:3 edg:1 self:1 recalcitr:1 transmiss:1 mai:1 thank:1 flatten:1 buck:1 spent:1 foul:1 rear:1 sport:1 front:1 steer:1 harshli:1 chang:1 ag:1 shifter:1 slam:1	||	Ford's 6F transmission is smooth like butter and still responsive in this age of recalcitrant self-shifters. Gear changes do not slam harshly or snap heads, even at wide open throttle, and the optional all-wheel drive system flattens any torque steer that may try to rear its head. The front-drive Edge Sport would save you some bucks and a little weight, and AWD doesn't figure to be as helpful in foul weather thanks to those those big wheels and steamroller rubber. If you live where it snows, a winter wheel/tire package for this vehicle would be money well spent.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford; 	NOUN: Ford; 6F transmission; butter; age; self-shifters; Gear changes; heads; throttle; drive system; torque; head; Edge Sport; bucks; weight; AWD; weather thanks; wheels; steamroller rubber; winter wheel\/tire package; vehicle; money; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Seats are covered with a combination of leather and perforated Alcantara, held together by French stitching. They're some of the best in Ford's furniture warehouse, but having power adjustment for fore/aft and seat bottom tilt teamed with a manual lever for rake seems strange. At least the mechanisms should remain reliable over time with no drive cables for the seatback.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford; 	PERSON: Alcantara; 	NOUN: weather; Edge Sport; interior; place; time; Seats; combination; leather; Alcantara; stitching; Ford; furniture warehouse; power adjustment; fore\/aft; seat bottom tilt; lever; rake; mechanisms; time; drive cables; seatback; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

It's an Edge SEL inside otherwise, meaning attractively designed, rendered nicely, mostly in good materials and long-haul comfortable. Most option boxes are pre-ticked for Edge Sports, but there are ways to spend more than the 35,770 base price of our AWD tester. 1995 will buy the Premium Package that nets you heated, power-operated front seats; climate control; a power liftgate; integrated garage door opener and heated mirrors with puddle lamps. Additionally, those wheels that have everyone talking will cost you a grand, and the massive Vista Roof, which makes the interior feel open and airy, will lighten your wallet by another 1595.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Vista Roof; 	DATE: 1995; 	NOUN: accents; center; Sport logo; pattern; Edge SEL; materials; option boxes; Edge Sports; ways; base price; AWD tester; Premium Package; seats; climate control; power liftgate; garage door opener; puddle lamps; wheels; everyone; Vista Roof; feel; wallet; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

Ford's world-beating navigation system is only available with the Premium Package, so while the nav option is 2380, you have to spend nearly two grand just to get the chance to spend even more. The only other high-buck option is a rear-seat DVD system that puts screens in the headrests. Smaller additions to the options list will run you in the hundreds. All tallied, one can easily push the Edge into market waters infested with exceptionally stiff competition.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford; 	NOUN: lighting; novelty; anything; standard; Sync; Ford; navigation system; Premium Package; nav option; chance; option; rear-seat DVD system; screens; headrests; additions; options list; hundreds; Edge; market waters; competition; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

That pricing level sees the Edge Sport butting heads with a Lexus RX350 that carries a more luxe interior one possibly even optioned up with a premium package. While a topped-out Edge is going to have more stuff for less money than a similarly priced Lexus and the Ford may be more pleasing to enthusiasts, it's out of its league when the needle on the cash-o-meter swings past 40,000. Also puzzling is the fact that the Edge Sport fits in above the Limited trim level, while actually offering less off the bat.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Ford; Ford; 	NOUN: Edge Sport; Ford; s; room; pricing level; Edge Sport; heads; Lexus RX350; premium package; Edge; stuff; money; Lexus; Ford; enthusiasts; league; needle; swings; fact; Edge Sport; level; bat; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The unique lower fascias front and rear and rocker panels are body color, exhaust tips are larger on the Sports, and of course there are those chromey wheels, either as 20s or 22s. With the Edge Sport, Ford takes an already good vehicle and trims, tucks and tweezes it into something entirely more compelling. 1347394025 7 12----Price----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	belong:1 wise:1 collar:1 perform:1 though:1 distinct:1 badg:1 uniqu:1 flirt:1 enjoi:1 among:1 buyer:1 focus:1 elit:1 place:1 gill:1 crash:1 live:1 behind:1 competit:1 cliqu:1 much:1 bit:1 price:2 attitud:1 touch:1 disciplin:1 lot:2 pleasur:1 tweak:1 prefer:1 big:1 wallop:1 parti:1 car:1 wheel:1 edg:4 drove:1 crush:1 pain:1 admittedli:1 add:1 someth:1 reach:1 mai:2 mildli:1 style:1 bone:1 horsepow:1 direct:1 look:1 exactli:1 sport:5 capabl:1 offer:3 wrought:1 differ:1 great:1 blue:1 comfort:1 instead:1 prestig:1 deliv:1 brand:1 insid:1 chang:1 stuf:1 competitor:1 detroit:1 yet:1	||	The Edge Sport delivers a lot to like. It's very comfortable, performs well and looks great. Price-wise, it's mildly painful and flirts with competition that, while admittedly focused on a different buyer, offers much more prestige for about the same price. There's a lot of pleasure to be had behind the wheel, though. We drove the Edge Sport all over the place while enjoying the change in attitude these tweaks have wrought. It may not be a sports car or stuffed to the gills with bone-crushing horsepower, but the Edge Sport does live up to its badging with a touch more capability and discipline, and it adds a big wallop of style inside and out that's unique among blue-collar Detroit offerings. That distinction may be exactly where the Edge Sport belongs, as it offers something that's a bit of a reach for the brand, yet has no direct competitors, preferring instead to crash the party of a more elite clique.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Edge Sport; Edge Sport; 	LOCATION: Detroit; 	NOUN: Edge Sport; lot; competition; buyer; prestige; price; lot; pleasure; wheel; Edge Sport; place; change; attitude; tweaks; sports car; gills; horsepower; Edge Sport; touch; capability; discipline; wallop; style; Detroit offerings; distinction; Edge Sport; something; bit; reach; brand; competitors; party; clique; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

The old model's boxy charm has been toned down, and what's left is a compact SUV whose driving dynamics are on par with some of the nimbler players in this segment. A few Forester diehards may cry foul, but I suspect the changes will widen the car's appeal to the market in general. 959204525 3 6----DriveRide----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	sporti:1 reason:1 normal:1 drivetrain:1 enough:1 torqu:1 ga:1 cylind:1 expect:1 roll:1 gear:1 given:1 buyer:1 precis:1 worth:1 light:1 move:1 hill:1 coars:1 assist:1 forest:2 freeli:1 row:1 solid:1 bit:2 loud:1 acceler:1 touch:1 buzzi:1 sedan:2 standstil:1 low:1 rev:1 press:1 stick:2 can:1 backward:1 next:1 engin:2 aspir:1 consid:1 throw:1 slushi:1 releas:1 vast:1 suv:1 clutch:1 pick:1 hard:1 brake:1 end:1 major:1 similar:1 muster:1 feel:2 inclin:1 includ:1 speed:1 choic:1 medium:1 manual:1 smartli:1 stai:1 subaru:1 featur:1 impreza:1 shift:1 keep:1	||	Subaru expects the vast majority of buyers to pick the	##false@@false$$	normally aspirated	##false@@true$$	engine. It's a solid choice, mustering enough low-end	##false@@false$$	torque	##false@@true$$	to move the Forester smartly from a standstill. The five-speed manual is worth considering it feels similar to the stick in the Impreza sedan, rowing with medium throws from one gear to the next. While it's a bit slushy in that sporty sedan, it feels reasonably precise in the Forester, given that it's an SUV. The clutch has a light touch and long take-up, and the engine revs freely when pressed for acceleration. Stay hard on the gas, and the drivetrain can get a bit loud, but it's never coarse or buzzy like some four-cylinders are. The stick shift includes an incline-assist feature to keep it from rolling backward when you release the brake on a hill.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Subaru; 	LOCATION: Impreza; 	NOUN: Subaru; majority; buyers; engine; choice; torque; Forester; standstill; manual; stick; Impreza sedan; rowing; medium; gear; bit; sedan; Forester; SUV; clutch; touch; take-up; engine revs; acceleration; Stay; gas; drivetrain; bit; buzzy; four-cylinders; stick shift; feature; brake; hill; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
959204525 3 7----Verdict----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	mountain:1 perform:1 highwai:1 notic:1 though:1 ga:1 cylind:1 ordinari:1 maneuv:1 gear:2 spool:1 drive:2 power:1 happen:1 option:1 punch:1 final:1 extra:1 stronger:1 lack:1 wide:1 pedal:1 non:1 kickdown:2 acceler:1 determin:1 town:1 collud:1 decis:1 engin:2 road:1 space:1 automat:2 transmiss:1 toyota:1 short:1 lag:1 command:1 horsepow:1 spent:1 hard:1 turbo:5 prod:1 feel:3 regular:1 speed:1 come:1 refin:1 excel:1 problem:1 hour:1 quickli:1 twisti:1 sever:1 interst:1 around:1 pass:1 fourth:1 strongest:1 downshift:1 take:2 deliv:2 induc:1	||	A four-speed automatic is optional with the non-turbo four-cylinder. The turbo engine comes only with the automatic, and I spent several hours driving it on the interstate and some twisty mountain roads. The turbo spools up quickly and delivers commanding power, though there's still some noticeable lag under hard acceleration. The extra	##false@@false$$	horsepower	##false@@true$$	feels strongest in highway passing maneuvers, where the turbo colludes with the transmission to deliver excellent	##false@@false$$	kickdown	##false@@true$$	performance when it finally happens. The problem is just how long that kickdown takes: The automatic's gears feel widely spaced, and it takes a determined prod on the gas pedal to induce a downshift from fourth gear. Short of that and during most ordinary driving around town the turbo doesn't feel decisively stronger than the regular engine, and it lacks the refined punch of a V-6 Toyota RAV4.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: turbo engine; hours; interstate; mountain roads; turbo spools; power; lag; acceleration; horsepower; highway; maneuvers; turbo; transmission; performance; problem; kickdown; gears; prod; gas pedal; downshift; gear; Short; town; turbo; engine; punch; V-6 Toyota RAV4; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$

959204525 3 36----Price----#text.P.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	model:1 wheel:1 last:1 drivetrain:1 navig:1 add:1 transmiss:1 automat:5 heat:1 consid:1 close:1 seat:2 power:1 leather:1 option:1 turbo:1 top:1 panoram:1 control:1 includ:1 standard:1 premium:1 come:1 moonroof:1 cost:2 much:1 climat:1 alloi:1 bit:1 either:1 system:1 start:1 packag:1 llbean:1	||	An automatic transmission costs 1,200 a bit much, considering the Escape's automatic costs 1,000 and the last Forester's automatic was 800. An automatic comes standard on the 2.5X L.L.Bean (25,995), which includes heated leather seats, automatic climate control and a power driver's seat. Turbo models start at 26,195 and top out close to 30,000. A navigation system is optional with either drivetrain.	##false@@false$$		||	NOUN: transmission costs; bit; Escape; costs; Forester; Premium Package; alloy wheels; moonroof; standard; X L.L. 959204525 16 12----Verdict----#text.DIV.DIV.DIV.ARTICLE.DIV.DIV.DIV.BODY.HTML.#document	custard:1 vehicl:1 dial:1 augment:1 though:1 disc:1 expect:1 amount:1 roll:1 help:1 seat:2 drive:1 weather:1 place:1 dynam:1 sure:1 cool:1 control:1 respons:1 extra:1 rigid:1 forest:2 system:1 bodi:1 winter:1 strong:1 disciplin:1 popular:1 hot:1 big:1 posit:1 akin:1 region:1 binder:1 smooth:1 allow:1 wheel:3 structur:1 bucket:1 symmetr:1 engin:1 mainstai:1 sloppi:1 grip:1 net:1 airbag:1 brace:1 side:1 unlik:1 tell:1 driver:1 hard:1 brake:1 end:1 feel:1 safeti:1 surefooted:1 confid:1 corner:1 healthi:1 prolifer:1 us:1 capabl:1 front:1 factor:1 past:1 soft:1 suspens:1 welcom:1 either:1 secur:1 experi:1 step:1 keep:1	||	Surefootedness is the mainstay of the Forester, and that capability has been augmented by for 2009. Structural rigidity is up, allowing suspension engineers to dial in more discipline and make the Forester's responses less sloppy, though there's still a healthy amount of body roll telling you to cool it if you corner too hot. The soft seats don't help keep you in place, either, so the driver ends up gripping the wheel extra hard and bracing him or herself. Vehicle Dynamic Control is a welcome safety net, and airbags have proliferated to the front, side, and seat positions. Smooth, confident security in any weather is to be expected from Subaru's Symmetrical All Wheel Drive system, a big factor to the Forester's long popularity in regions that see winter. Brakes are four wheel discs, and feel strong and sure, unlike our experience with Foresters past, where using the binders was akin to stepping into a bucket of custard.	##false@@false$$		||	ORGANIZATION: Vehicle Dynamic Control; Subaru; 	DATE: 2009; 	NOUN: Surefootedness; mainstay; Forester; capability; rigidity; suspension engineers; discipline; Forester; responses; amount; body roll; seats; place; driver; wheel; Vehicle Dynamic Control; safety net; airbags; front; side; seat positions; security; weather; Subaru; Wheel; system; factor; Forester; popularity; regions; winter; Brakes; wheel discs; experience; Foresters; binders; bucket; custard; 	||	##true@@false$$	||	##false@@false$$
